fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let c be an object in a category C, and let J be any category. The constant functor at c is the functor J\xrightarrow {c} C that sends every object of J to c and every morphism of J to the identity 1_c.

The constant functors induce a functor C\xrightarrow {\Delta } J^C to the functor category which sends each object of C to the corresponding constant functor and each morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y to the natural transformation with components \alpha _j = f for each j\in J.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

Let \hat {C} be a presheaf category. Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {\Omega } Set be the sieve functor, which sends an object x to the set of sieves on x, and a map y\xrightarrow {f}x to its action on sieves by restriction: (\Omega f)(S) = \{g: fg\in S\}. Let *\xhookrightarrow {\top } \Omega (where * is the constant functor at the singleton) identify for each x\in C the maximal sieve. Then \top is a subobject classifier in \hat {C}.

Let Q\hookrightarrow P be a subobject in \hat {C}. We need to define the classifying natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\chi _Q}\Omega ; we work in components. At an object x\in C, this map must send an element p\in Px to a sieve on x; we choose the sieve (\chi _Q)_x(p) = \{z\xrightarrow {f} x\in C: p|_f \in Qz\}. In other words, this sieve consists of those maps which restrict p to an element of Q.

Next, to show that it is a pullback, it suffices to show that it is a pullback at each x\in C, and by the construction of limits in Set, it suffices to show that (\chi _Q)_x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. The backwards direction is already done; conversely, if it is the maximal sieve, then we obtain the result by observing that 1_x\in (\chi _Q)_x(p) and applying the definition of \chi _Q.

Finally, to show uniqueness, suppose that we have another natural transformation P\xrightarrow {\theta } \Omega . By the above argument, for the square to be a pullback, we must have that \theta _x(p) is the maximal sieve if and only if p\in Qx. Now further, given z\xrightarrow {f} x and applying the same fact at z, we must have that p|_f\in Qz if and only if \theta _z(p|_f) is the maximal sieve. By naturality of \theta at a map f, we have that \theta _z(p|_f) = \Omega f(\theta _x(p)), which by definition of \Omega is the maximal sieve if and only if f\in \theta _x(p). As a consequence, if the square is a pullback, we must have that f\in \theta _x(p) if and only if p|_f\in Qz, yielding exactly the definition of \chi _Q above.

We prove the result for limits and conclude for colimits by duality. For any diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C, the definition of \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D) is the set of natural transformations c\to D, which by definition is the set of cones \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c). A right adjoint \operatorname *{lim}_J to this functor is thus characterized by the natural isomorphism \operatorname {Hom}(\Delta c, D)\cong \operatorname *{Cone}_D(c)\cong C(c, \operatorname *{lim}_J D), which is the definition of the limit. Thus pointwise the right adjoint and the limit agree, and so the right adjoint extends uniquely to the limit functor.

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

fr:title.text: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is a right adjoint if and only if, for each c\in C, the comma category c\downarrow G has an initial object. Dually, C\xrightarrow {F} D is a left adjoint if and only if, for each d\in D, the comma category F\downarrow d has a terminal object. (Here, c is the constant functor at c.)
In the forwards direction, we obtain the result since adjoint assignments are universal and universal elements are initial in exactly the specified category of elements.

In the backwards direction, let c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} Gd_0 be initial in c\downarrow G; let Fc = d_0. Initiality of \eta _c means that, for any map c\to Gd, there is a unique map Fc\to d in D making the triangle commute. In other words, \eta _c determines a bijection C(c, Gd)\cong D(Fc, d). Moreover, this bijection is natural in D, since it comes from the natural isomorphism which defines the colimit \eta _c. Thus, this data extends to an adjunction.

fr:title.text: The constant diagram functor commutes with functors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The constant diagram functor commutes with functors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The constant diagram functor \Delta commutes with other functors. In particular, for any category J and functor C\xrightarrow {F} D, C\xrightarrow {\Delta } C^J\xrightarrow {F_*} D^J= C\xrightarrow {F} D\xrightarrow {\Delta } D^J.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: On the left, we have the action c\mapsto (j\mapsto c)\mapsto (j\mapsto c\mapsto Fc); on the right, we have the action c\mapsto Fc\mapsto (j\mapsto Fc). These agree.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A cocone (or just cone) under a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with nadir c\in C is a natural transformation D\xrightarrow {\lambda } c, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism Dj\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} c, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cocone are called its colegs or just legs.

A cone over a diagram J\xrightarrow {D} C with apex c\in C is a natural transformation c\xrightarrow {\lambda } D, where c is the constant functor at c. Explicitly, a cone consists of, for each object j\in J, a morphism c\xrightarrow {\lambda _j} Dj, so that for each morphism j\xrightarrow {f}k\in J, the following diagram commutes:
The components \lambda _j of the cone are called its legs.

fr:title.text: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Set is complete â€º construction of limits in Set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C and D be categories. The functor category D^C has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as identities, the identity natural transformations.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A natural transformation F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G between functors C\xrightarrow {F,G} D consists of, for every object x\in C, a morphism \alpha _x: Fx\to Gx (the components) such that, for every morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y in C, the following diagram commutes:
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
